div.l: Til he were nygh out of his p̉rentisehood
Al were he snybbed erly and late
And somtyme lad with reuel to Newgate
But atte laste his maister hym bi þoughte
Vpon a day whan he his papir soughte
Of a ꝓproủerbe þᵗat seith þis same word
Wel bet is roten appil out of hord
Than þᵗat it rote al the remenant
So fareth by a riotons seruant
It is ful lasse harme to late hym pace
Than he shende alle the s̉eruᵃauntes in þe place
Therfore his maister ȝaf hym a quitance
And bad hym goon with sorwe ⁊and meschance
And þus þis ioly p̉rentys hadde his leue
Now let hym riote al þe nyght or leue
And for ther is no theef wᵗithoute a lowke
That helpeth hym to wasten ⁊and to sowke
Of þᵗat he bribe can / or borwe may
Anoon he sente his bed and his aray
Vn to a compere of his owne sort
That loued dys Reuel and disport
And hadde a wyf þat heeld for countenᵃaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for hir sustenᵃaunce
But here of I wol passe as now
And of ȝonge Gamelyn I wol telle ȝow
¶ The tale of ȝonge Gamelyn ~
Lithen and lesteneth and herkeneth aright
And ȝe shul here of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn of Boundes was his name
He coude of norture and moche game
Thre sones þe knyght hadde ⁊and with his body hem wan
The eldest was a moche shrewe ⁊and sone he bigan
His bretheren loued wel her fader ⁊and of hym were a gast
The eldest deserued his fader cors ⁊and had it atte last
The goode knyght his fader lyued so ȝore
That deth was comen hym to ; and handeled hym ful sore
The goode knyght cared sore sike there he lay
How his children shulde lyue ; after his day
He hadde ben wyde where but non husbond he was
